title: The veil between our world and theirs is growing thinner | Paranormal Corner
text:
Ever since I can remember, it seems like there's a certain exciting feeling in the air during Halloween time . 
The closer the calendar gets to the last day of October, the more electric the atmosphere becomes. 
When I was younger, I thought those feelings just stemmed from my love of the holiday. 
But as I grew older and became more interested in the history, legends, and mysteries of All Hallows Eve , I discovered that the change in the air wasn't merely my imagination. 
Pagan legends that date back thousands of years say that on Oct. 31, the veil between our world and the spirit world is at its thinnest, allowing the dead to walk among us. 
No, not zombie style. 
The belief is that spirits can cross over to the land of the living more easily on Halloween night. 
Many Halloween traditions are based on these Pagan beliefs including the most popular one — dressing up in costumes. 
The Celts dressed as spirits on All Hallows Eve because they believed they would blend in with the spirits that crossed through the veil that night. 
They also believe that, because Halloween falls exactly between the Autumnal Equinox and Winter Solstice, the day holds potent magical properties. 
Hundreds of years ago, people would invite the dead home to feast with their loved ones or to come in out of the cold. Other customs included leaving food out for family members who had passed on, and even performing rituals to aid in communicating with the dead. 
While I've never held a ghostly dinner party or ordered a spiritual pizza for the dead, Oct. 31 has always felt different to me, from the moment the sun appears in the morning, until the final stroke of midnight. 
I can remember sensing that feeling from the moment I opened my eyes on Halloween morning when I was a child. MORE : WATCH: The search for the Jersey Devil 
And if Halloween fell on a school day, that day was like no other of the entire year — wearing your costume in class, parading through the school and around the playground, playing games, and listening to scary stories like my all-time favorites from music class including, " The Skinny Toe ." Never heard of it? Look it up. 
Finally, the dismissal bell would clang — seemingly louder and creepier on that day — and as soon as I climbed off the bus at home, mom and I would start setting up for the trick or treaters. 
The house would already be decorated for the most part, but there were special items that only came out on Halloween night. 
There were plastic molded pumpkin and scarecrow lights, the yearly jack-o-lantern, and — my favorite piece — a ghost made on a seamstress' dress form mannequin. 
Mom would place one of my rubber kickballs on the mannequin's cardboard "neck," slide a yardstick horizontally through the back of the form to simulate arms, then drape a white sheet over the round head to create a classic ghost. 
Two black ovals cut from construction paper and taped on the face, and my dad's old work boots poking out from under the sheet, completed the piece de resistance. 
You wouldn't believe how many kids would come in for their treat and stare at that contraption like it was going to move at any second. 
Some kids literally had to look under the sheet before they believed it was not a person waiting to pounce. 
That is the kind of magic that Halloween produces. 
Thousands of young imaginations — and older ones alike — firing simultaneously, plus the natural energy brought about by the equinox and impending solstice all fusing together is what brings Halloween to life all around us every chilly October. 
Kelly Roncace is senior investigator and team leader with Jersey Unique Minds Paranormal Society , a professional paranormal investigation team based in Salem County.
